awd_titl_txt: Promoting Robotic Design and Entrepreneurship Experiences among Students and Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will develop, implement, and assess an initiative to promote robotic design and entrepreneurship experiences among students and teachers. Each year, 16 teachers and 32 students from 8 high schools located in all 5 boroughs of New York will attend a 4-week summer institute consisting of a 2-week guided training and a 2-week collaborative robotic-product development. The participants will come primarily from schools in underserved neighborhoods with socially, economically, racially, and ethnically diverse student bodies; approximately half of the participants will be female. During the academic year, each school's two teachers will conduct a robotics course for at least 25 students. Classroom adoption will be facilitated through a professional learning community (PLC). In the annual grand finale, school teams will compete in a robot product design and business idea contest, modeled after the Inno/Vention contest coordinated by the Incubator Initiatives of NYU Tandon School of Engineering. Over the 3-year project duration, 48 teachers and 96 students from 24 high schools will participate in the summer institute with 160 contact hours. Through the academic year elective, teachers will engage 1,200 students during the project funding period. The project has formed an interdisciplinary team including experts in robotics, entrepreneurship, K-12 curriculum design, and assessment to support project design and implementation. 

The project design adapts features from research on project-based learning (PBL), robotics and entrepreneurship in K-12 STEM education, social cognitive career theory, and teacher professional development embedded in a PLC. Formulating robotics activities in a PBL framework will help participants learn content, develop planning and problem-solving skills, and foster their higher-order cognitive skills. Integration of PBL with entrepreneurship activities will address participant fear of failure, lack of confidence, and creativity and communication skills. The design of the teacher professional development will support transfer of training through content-immersion, allow modeling and rehearsing of desired skills, and involve teachers for a sufficient duration to support the cognitive demands of new learning. The project will research the broad overarching question: Do robotics design and entrepreneurship activities, experienced through PBL, positively influence teacher practices and student outcomes? The project will investigate if participation (1) builds teacher capacity to effectively utilize PBL, contextualized in robotics and entrepreneurship, to promote STEM learning and (2) positively impacts students self-efficacy, outcome expectations, goals, and interest in STEM studies and careers. This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program that supports projects that build understandings of best practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to engaging students in learning and developing interest in STEM, information and communications technology (ICT), computer science, and related STEM content and careers.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: From 2017-2020, this project provided professional development (PD) to 44 teachers from 26 high schools and educational enrichment to 96 students. The project adapted features from evidence-based research on project-based learning (PBL), robotics and entrepreneurship in STEM education, social cognitive career theory, and effective PD guidelines embedded in a professional learning community (PLC). Each year, a four-week summer workshop, with engineering facilitators as mentors, provided PD to teachers and educational enrichment to their students within a PBL framework focused on robotics design and entrepreneurship. Each year's workshop included two-week guided training and two-week capstone projects. Workshop curriculum included essential concepts required to initiate a novice in building robotics devices. Corresponding to each concept lesson, participants performed hands-on activities in teams of two teachers and four to five students. For the capstone project, participant teams performed engineering design, prototyping, and testing to produce robots for competing on a mock-up game field inspired from real-world socially relevant robotics challenges conceived by the project staff and aligned with the PBL framework. The workshop was expected to provide several benefits to the participants. First, they were expected to gain familiarity with and understanding of the robotics fundamentals. Second, the teachers were to be supported during the academic year (AY) to integrate robotics curriculum and projects in classrooms and after-school programs. Third, the students were encouraged to participate in an end-of-year robotics contest

 

Through teachers' incorporation of robotics learning in classrooms, clubs, or after-school programs, many students were introduced to robotics via hands-on learning. Each year, student teams participated in robotics contests that integrated entrepreneurial explorations and technology creation while being guided to make meaningful contributions to their communities. Teachers adapted the workshop curriculum for their students' needs. Workshop's student attendees supported teachers during hands-on learning sessions. Each year, four to five graduate engineering facilitators weekly visited schools to observe and support classroom robotics activities. The facilitators and teachers collaborated to create worksheets, conduct hands-on activities, debug circuits and codes, and assess student work. These activities engaged a total of 618 students many of whom had not been exposed to robotics or entrepreneurship previously.

 

Robotics self-efficacy, familiarity, and content knowledge are relevant factors to gauge the ability of teachers to deliver robotics learning to students. Accordingly, using two survey instruments and a technical quiz, we investigated whether the workshop contributed to any changes in participants' robotics self-efficacy, familiarity, and content knowledge. To examine the impact of AY activities, we considered design artifacts submitted for the end-of-year robotics contests. Through the examination of the pre/post survey and quiz responses, for teachers and students, numerous statistically significant changes with medium to very large effect sizes were seen in their levels of robotics self-efficacy, familiarity, and content knowledge.  The results of observations, reflections, and reviews of students' robotics designs, under the capstone projects and contests, indicate that students gained an appreciation for the real-world relevance of science, math, and robotics content knowledge and honed 21st century skills. The results suggest that robotics education programs can produce learning gains among participants, a finding that is promising for education researchers and professional development providers interested in leveraging the potential of robotics in STEM education.

 

Broader Impact: A significant proportion of ITEST participants are from groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. For example, the summer workshop participants who completed demographics information included 44 teachers (19 female, 9 Black, and 7 Hispanic teachers) and 91 students (34 female, 17 Black, and 21 Hispanic students). Each teacher received two kits of robotics components. The robotics kits were used by the teacher-student teams during workshop to conduct hands-on learning during the guided training phase. Several educational robotics companies supported the workshops by delivering day or two-day long modules and provided corresponding robotics materials to teachers. Teachers took all robotics kits back to their school for appropriate use. Through the AY activities, project teachers impacted teaching and learning of 618 students who included 336 female students and 433 students from racial and ethnic groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Project's curriculum development, PD, classroom implementation, and robotics research activities have led to several educational and technical publications (journal articles: 1, and conference proceedings: 8).

 

The PIs, graduate student researchers, and engineering education research personnel of the project disseminated robotics educational activities through workshops, seminars, and expos. Three doctoral and three masters students (partially supported under the project) and six masters students (supported under philanthropic funds) engaged in various project related activities (e.g., robotics education, lesson development, school visits). An additional eight visiting undergraduates reviewed, tested, and revised the robotics curriculum or contributed to a design canvas based assessment of capstone design projects. These activities broadened the training of researchers, sensitizing them to the needs of K-12 constituencies and enabling them to develop a deeper understanding of the relevance of their research to the K-12 environment.
